Locking heroes behind a paywall ruined the game. 

Every time a new hero drops, you will get bodied because you can't learn how to play them and consequenly how to counter them properly. They are always super OP on release and grinding for them takes way too long if you don't make this game a second job. By the time you actually get your hands on them, they get patched to shit. So if you don't pony up 10 bucks, you're gonna have a bad time. 

The rest of the battle pass is absolute worthless trash, it is genuinely the single most terrible BP I've ever seen. 90% of the content is absolute useless trash that nobody uses, you don't get enough credits for shit and chances are most of the skins won't be for characters you actually play anyway.

5v5 is also a bad change, it puts an insane amount of pressure on the tank. Games are decided on the hero select screen if your tank player is bad because there's nobody to pick up the slack.

I don't even want to get into the disaster that is the PVE launch, The whole point of Relaunching as OW2 ended up just being a bunch of broken promises.

Activision Blizzard's greed ruined one of the most promising and profitable IP's ever chasing the foolish dream of infinite growth.

Worst sequel ever
Thank you Blizzard for the scam

One of the biggest cash-grabs and fumbles in gaming history. Realistically, the signs were there from the first balance patch in 2016.

Now, the game only cares about siphoning as much money from your wallet as it can. PvE was cancelled (y'know, the whole reason for the sequel in the first place) and replaced with buyable missions, most of which seem to be around or below the quality of previously free 'story' events.

The competitive integrity of the game is a joke. After years of fostering a culture of "you can play whatever you want in comp, you don't even have to try to win", Blizzard now wonders why nobody wants to play competitive. Not to mention of course the massive smurfing issues, which would only be exacerbated by F2P, if anyone still cared enough.

Cheaters are rampant and regular, both the well-hidden and the obvious. Every balance change is completely nonsensical and thrown together with no critical thought. Their brand new "hero progression" is also a watered-down restoration of the previous system, which they [i][b]chose[/b][/i] to remove to put the focus on MTX.

However, most importantly of all, Blizzard have just ruined the game. It's not fun, it's not challenging, it's just a yawn fest of visual noise and no rewards. I don't think I've ever quite seen a sequel be such a downgrade from a product that was already failing, and the only reason for the sequel is the cash shop. Don't waste your time, TF2 and even Paladins are much, much better.

The decision to replace the cherished Overwatch (1) servers with Overwatch 2 has left a bitter aftertaste, introducing an overpriced cash shop and an unoriginal, linear battle pass system. Both of these changes appear to prioritize monetization over player satisfaction due to FOMO and inseparable cash shop bundles.

Among the significant letdowns is the abandonment of the promised PvE Hero Missions and power progression. These were initially promoted as the game's unique selling points and the very reasons justifying the sequel. The emphasis has now shifted towards PvP modes. While we did receive Story Missions, they now come at a cost and are going to be infrequent seasonal releases. This absence of Hero Missions and progression creates a void in the gameplay experience, stripping away the anticipated core PvE mode.

While Overwatch 2 retains the vibrant and captivating hero-based shooter that drove its predecessor to success, it stumbles notably in several aspects. Ongoing balance issues, disarray within the competitive scene, role queues, and character skins that often feel like mere cash grabs â€“ straying frequently from the character's theme â€“ all contribute to this setback. Furthermore, game balance itself faces a potential compromise, as new heroes remain inaccessible behind a paywall. As a result, those who choose not to pay may very well find themselves at a disadvantage in certain scenarios.

The game's visual and artistic components continue to amaze with intricate character designs and lively environments. However, these strengths can only go so far in compensating for the content deficiencies.

The potential of the rich and captivating world of Overwatch has been overshadowed by these questionable monetization tactics and lackluster decision-making. The game's unique heroes and villains deserve a better home where their stories and gameplay potential can flourish without being hindered by corporate strategies that prioritize profits over player satisfaction.

Why should I play Overwatch 2 when I can play Team Fortress 2 and Paladins for an objectively better experience?

Team Fortress 2 is specifically built around having fun, not nickel & diming players. It also has a fun PvE mode with a fairly extensive upgrade system. PvE is also FREE, and offers a variety of waves & maps to play in to ensure its fun to replay.

Paladins has the hero talents & upgrades as a part of their CORE gamemode, and there's much more potential to operate independently, than than you can in Overwatch 2.
